Noooooo, no never. As long as nearly all the computer screens in the universe are enabled only or primarily to _preview print on computer screens_, print will never die! ;)

 [rich](http://web.archive.org/web/20120622224407/http:/readableweb.com/)

The story is not a fake. I read the Baltimore Sun take on it sitting here in my 'jammies. Print is not dead yet, but dying a slow cancerous death as an unneeded middle medium. I can probably get anything from here at my desk that I could have gotten from the 20,000 books at the Cushing Library. However, access to a $12,000 cappuccino maker is something I really do need to go there for.

\> As long as nearly all the computer screens in the universe  
\> are enabled only or primarily to preview print  
\> on computer screens, print will never die! ;)

believe it or not, david, in spite of all those clues you left,  
i didn't know that was sarcasm until i hit the winky smilie,  
because lots of people actually \_believe\_ that line o' crap.

print will never die. not until most of the trees die first.  
(and humans won't have long to live after that happens.)

but bookstores, especially the big chains? well, borders  
probably has 2-5 years left, and barnes & noble 5-10...  
spare us your whimpering. didn't help record-stores any.

-bowerbird

Actually, the trees will kill us first: it turns out if (read: when) global  
temperatures go up a little bit more, trees start _releasing_ CO2 instead  
of absorbing it... Intelligent Design? :-/

hhp

\>...until i hit the winky smilie, because lots of people actually \_believe\_ that line o’ crap.

What line of crap? Adobe, Apple and MS all claim to "render the screen as close as possible to the printed page".  
One over does it, one does it right, and one under does it. Until they care more about the screen, people will need to print from the screen to read it, or buy books. Reading will die before printing, because french fries need to be boxed.

Cheers!

Everytime they renovate the library at my college, the area for books gets smaller and more PCs are added. I would say that about 15% of the space is for books now. (They recently eliminated the LP record collection, and stacked them up on the staff lounge table, free for the taking. Someone more industrious than me could probably clear a grand or more selling those things on Ebay.)

david said:  
\> What line of crap?

well, i said "line o' crap", not "line of crap". but, it was this one...

\> As long as nearly all the computer screens in the universe

"in the universe"? that's a pretty clear signal you're talking crap.  
hyperbole and sarcasm are great friends; they vacation together.

and "nearly all" is yet another clear signal. judging by the numbers  
for internet-exploder-6-and-7, many of our computer screens now  
(even in the first world) are hooked up to aging p.c. machines which  
might not even have (working) printers attached to them any more...  
and inkjet printers (and dot-matrix?) aren't exactly known for quality,  
especially when their users are stretching the cartridges to save cash.

\> are enabled only or primarily to preview print on computer screens,  
\> print will never die! ;)

again, the word "only" here is an \_obvious\_ tipoff that this is sarcasm,  
and "primarily" right behind it just means that it's not purely sarcastic.

the notion that any significant number of people print out their e-mail  
to read it was buried -- along with those oldsters -- in the last century.

and i've never heard -- not even once, not even in jest, mind you -- that  
people print out their twitterstream to read it. (but it'd be a good joke!)

nor do we hear about blog posts being printed, or facebook pages,  
or myspace pages, or wikipedia articles, or live-journal pages, or...

and if you're gonna print out stuff from a news-site, you might as well  
have bought the newspaper, and we all know how newspapers are doing.

so the only way your sentence makes any sense is to turn it on its head:  
the only reason people still use print is to proofread stuff for the screen.

and given the apparent absence of proofreading out there in the world,  
i'd say there isn't even much of \_that\_ type of printing going on...

cory said it years ago, and it only becomes more true as time passes by:  
more and more we are reading less from paper, and more from the screen.

\> people will need to print from the screen to read it, or buy books

well, there you go! bookstores! tomorrow's growth industry! for sure!

-bowerbird

just so you know, i've found that  
when i get funny wrapping on my posts,  
i can just resize the window and/or the typesize,  
and it all straightens out.

so you might want to try that...

-bowerbird

Wow someone woke up on the wrong side of the kitty litter

I was referring to a relationship between print and screen that's obviously eluded you

Cheers

Chris, do you know what happens when a grenade is thrown into a French kitchen (I just learnt today)?

Going back to the original thread, Cushing Academy's decision to discard or give away the library books and replace them with e-readers and a cappuccino machine: Why did it have to be either/or? If I were paying [in the mid-30s](http://web.archive.org/web/20120622224407/http:/www.cushing.org/admission/tuition.shtml) to send my kid to high school, I'd expect e-readers, cappuccino, and books too.

I would ask the same question to publishers and readers: _Why does it have to be either/or?_ Hard-copy books are still a choice; they're often a good choice. They're just not the _only_ choice anymore.
